goal.ch: ME3053 is an introductory modern physics course designed for mechanical engineering students in their junior or senior year. Modern physics, developed in the early 20th century, introduces revolutionary concepts and theories—such as relativity and quantum mechanics—that contrast with classical physics (19th century and earlier). The applications of modern physics are extensive, spanning nuclear science (e.g., nuclear energy, nuclear medicine), materials science (e.g., semiconductors, nanomaterials), and electronics (e.g., semiconductor and nanoscale devices). The primary goal of ME3053 is to familiarize students with the fundamental ideas and principles of modern physics, preparing them for advancements in future technologies.

outline.ch: ME3053 covers major concepts of modern physics, including the special theory of relativity, wave-particle duality, matter waves, the Schrödinger equation and its application to the hydrogen atom, atomic physics, statistical physics, and the physics of molecules and solids.
